office:text.text:p: Petar Tomov, Iliyan Zankinski, Todor Balabanov
Institute of Information and Communication Technologies - Bulgarian Academy of Sciences
akad. Georgi Bonchev Str., block. 2, office 514, 1113 Sofia, Bulgaria

text:p.text:span: This research addresses reverse engineering of a well know problem in the slot machine gambling games development. Modern slot machines have virtual reels which usually are trade secrete of the manufacture. The virtual reels are the discrete random distribution of the game. In the game play virtual reels are the base of return to player (RTP) calculation. If someone wants to check the RTP he/she will need to reconstruct the virtual reels by visual observations of the different game screens. The idea of the solution proposed in this research is to apply Monte-Carlo search technique in order to reconstruct slot machine virtual reels.
Keywords:
monte-carlo search
slot machines
reconstruction
reverse engineering

Modern slot machines are computerized gambling devices which can offer different games. Such machines can be found in many gambling halls, casino or bars. Operating a slot machine is much more cost efficient than classical gambling games like poker, black jack or roulette. It is one of the main reasons slot machines to be so popular. It shows also that they are very profitable for the owners. A classic electronic slot machines consists of five virtual reels and only three rows are visible. Reels spins when start button is pressed and each reel stops at particular randomly chosen position. Pay offs are formed according predefined line patterns (usually from left to right). Each slot machine game has pay table in which different symbols are differentiated according their value in combination.

The main scope of the paper is discrete probability distribution of the symbols over the virtual reels. Each virtual reel consists of symbols (programmatically usually presented as numbers). The order of the symbols is subject of game design and usually it is done by statisticians, but not only [

]. Mathematicians who are responsible for the slot machine game design should select such symbols distribution which will produce certain RTP. Symbols distribution is not only related to the RTP, but it is also related to the game volatility and overall game play feeling. RTP of the game is calculated by dividing total won money over total lost money, multiplied by one hundred in order to represent percentage. The RTP is common slot machine characteristics and it is under government laws regulation. The mathematical meaning of RTP is an expected value. The RTP is important in this research, because it is the only way to approve how accurate are the reconstructed reels. Even that the reels are not known (as trade secrete) the pay table, betting lines and the RTP of each game are pretty well known. The main idea in the reels reconstruction is that the reconstructed reels will show exact or near to the known RTP.

text:section.text:p: In order to clarify better why reels reconstruction is so important some brief explanation of the slot machine reels will be given.

text:p.text:span: The basic concept of the game are the spinning reels. Historically first slot machines were mechanical. The mechanical reels were driven to spin by manual handle pull. Most modern games of this type are computerized and mechanical reels are replaced with virtual reels which stops according pseudo-random number generator (PRNG) outcome [1]. Mechanical handle was replaced by start button which drives the reels to spin. After certain period of time reels stop one by one. Win is calculated according symbols patterns appeared on the screen. Different symbols are different profitable, which is well defined as pay table, usually available on the second screen. More frequent symbols are less profitable, but less frequent symbols are much more informative for reels reconstruction process.

For the quality of reels reconstruction RTP is used. This parameter can be in the range of 80% (Las Vegas gambling halls) up to 98% in some European member states. Fruit machines in the United Kingdom, for example, are required by law to pay out a minimum percentage within a short period of time [2]. In most government regulations the RTP is 90% or above. In order the desired RTP to be achieved mathematicians and game designers are working in collaboration to populate game reels with proper symbols in proper discrete distribution [3].

The task for reels reconstruction is pretty similar to the task of new reels construction. The main difference is related with the game screen observation done and the requirement the observed patterns to be presented in the reconstructed reels.
In the literature Monte-Carlo Search is better know as Monte-Carlo Tree Search
(MCTS). We will use the term Monte-Carlo Search because in the case of this research the structure of optimization is a graph structure not a tree structure
MCS is a heuristic search algorithm
in decision construction process
It has its common use in the game play.
MCS is used in cases where building of
a graph
is so time consuming that all exact number algorithms are inefficient.
Games like Chess and Go are the most popular examples of MCS usage.
MCS is applicable not only in deterministic games but it also can be used in games like Poker.
The basic of MCS is the analysis of the most promising further constructions.
Search options are expanded according random sampling of the search space.
The application of MCS in the process is based on many
atempts
At each run reel is reconstructed to the maximum allowed length by selecting
observed patterns
at random.
Each reel reconstruction is evaluated according very well defined reel start, reel end and very rare game dependent patterns.
In the core of the proposed algorithm is the idea for screen pattern classification and the usage of this patterns as operation in finite state machine.

As input for the algorithm screen observations are used. Each reel is observed specified number of times (experimentally about 600 times). Observed patterns can be written manually, but image processing algorithms can be used for automated symbols identification. Picture of the slot machine screens is relatively static which makes it perfect candidate for image processing procedures.
Data input processing is as follows:

text:section.text:p: 1. Input data as sequence of characters (observed patterns).
2. Identify unique patterns and put them as nodes in transitions graph.

text:p.text:span: 2.1 For each node check matching with the others.
2.2 If match store as edge in transitions graph.
2.3 If does not match repeat 2.1.

text:section.text:p: 3. Calculate symbols frequencies in observed patterns.
4. Initialize reel start with well known starting pattern.
4.1 Select random transition according current reel ending.
4.2 Repeat until reel maximum length is reached or end pattern appears.
6. Go to 4 until predefined amount of time is not reached.

text:p.text:span: In step 2.1 one pattern matches anther if the end of the first pattern can be found in the beginning of the second pattern. Symbols frequencies in observed patterns (step 3) is used as statistical estimation for the quality of generated solution. If the frequencies of symbols in the generated reel are close to the frequencies of observed patterns the generated reel should be closer to the original one. Because of the less frequent symbols in the reels each virtual reel can be described with very well known pattern for start and end. These patterns are usually around special symbols. Very well known patterns can be checked in between of start and end patterns. Such patterns are used as control sequences. In step 5 three different types of evaluation is done. In first place symbols frequencies are calculated. Euclidean distance is calculated between the two frequencies vectors. After that counting of missing observed patterns in the generated reel is done. Finally generated pattern is disassembled on peaces with size of the observed patterns and each piece is counted if it is missing in the transitions nodes list. If the piece is missing in the list it means that the reel has piece which was not observed during data collection stage.
All the experiments performed and the results achieved are done with the
Java
program
developed especial for this research
E
xperiments are
done
on a desktop computer with MacOS Sierra 10.12.2 operating system, the 2.3 GHz Intel Core i5 processor and 8 GB of RAM Java Version 8 Update 112 (64bit).
Reel generation was done in 24 hours run of the software.
It shows that generated solutions have different level of correctness. In most of the cases generated reels were missing the control sequences.
Visualization of the missing observed patterns and extra not observed patterns is very helpful in the process of the manual fixing.
Because of the MCS probabilistic nature finding the exact extreme is time consuming and not very probable.
When all game presented reels are generated the game RTP is calculated and according to its closeness with the real RTP declared by the game manufacturer quality of the solution is evaluated.

Experiments shows that absolutely automatic reconstruction is not possible with MCS technique, but with some manual adjustments reconstructed reels are pretty close to originals at least as RTP achieved.
As further research it will be interesting reconstruction approach to be extended to optimization with evolutionary algorithms and/or context-sensitive grammar (CSG) as described in [4, 5]
This work was supported by a private funding of Velbazhd Software LLC.

text:section.text:p: [1] Brysbaert, M.: Algorithms for randomness in the behavioral sciences: A tutorial Behavior Research Methods, Instruments, and Computers vol.22, issue 1, p.45-60, (1991).

[2] Parke, J., Griﬃths, M.: The psychology of the fruit machine: The role of structural characteristics (revisited), Paper presented at the annual conference of The BritishPsychological Society, Surrey, England (2001).
[3] Osesa, N.: Bitz and Pizzas Optimal stopping strategy for a slot machine bonus game, OR Insight, 22, p.3144, (2009).

[4] Balabanov, T.: Distributed evolutional model for music composition by human-computer interaction. Proceedings of International Scientific Conference UniTech15, University publishing house V. Aprilov, Gabrovo, Bulgaria, vol. 2, 389-392 (2015).

[5] Balabanov, T.: Avoiding Local Optimums in Distributed Population based Heuristic Algorithms (in Bulgarian). Proceedings of XXIII International Symposium Management of energy, industrial and environmental systems, John Atanasoff Union of Automation and Informatics, Sofia, Bulgaria, p.83-86 (2015).
[6] Balabanov, T.: Slot Machine Reel Mosaicing, https://github.com/TodorBalabanov/Slot-Machine-Reel-Mosaicing Sofia, Bulgaria (2017).

[7] Balabanov T., Zankinski I., Shumanov B.: Slot Machines RTP Optimization with Genetic Algorithms. In: Dimov I., Fidanova S., Lirkov I. (eds) Numerical Methods and Applications. NMA 2014. Lecture Notes in Computer Science, vol 8962. Springer, Cham (2015).

[8] Balabanov T., Zankinski I., Shumanov B.: Slot Machine RTP Optimization and Symbols Wins Equalization with Discrete Differential Evolution. In: Lirkov I., Margenov S., Wasniewski J. (eds) Large-Scale Scientific Computing. Lecture Notes in Computer Science, vol 9374. Springer, Cham (2015).

[9] Keremedchiev D., Tomov P., Barova M.: Slot Machine Base Game Evolutionary RTP Optimization. In: Dimov I., Farago I., Vulkov L. (eds) Numerical Analysis and Its Applications. NAA 2016. Lecture Notes in Computer Science, vol 10187. Springer, Cham (2017).
